bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, April 11, 1924

div1.p: Kean informs Emilie Lawrence Reed that he wrote to the editor of World's Work to dispute the claims made by Marie Gorgas as regards the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, April 11, 1924
div1.opener:
RPB-S-31-23 - 100,000
JRK/FM
IN REPLY
REFER TO
HEADQUARTERS FIRST CORPS AREA
ARMY BASE
BOSTON 9. MASS.
11 April 1924.
Mrs. Walter Reed,
The Burlington,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I wrote last Sunday and sent to the Surgeon General
the inclosed letter about the article by Mrs. Gorgas and Mr.
Hendrick. He returned it with a very hearty note of approval
and with the suggestion that it be sent to the Editor of the
World's Work for publication. I did this yesterday. This
morning it occurred to me to look up Mr. Burton J. Hendrick
and see what was his address. I knew him as a writer of note,
especially in connection with the life and letters of Ambassa-
dor Walter Hines Page. What was my surprise and pleasure to
find that he is with Doubleday, Page & Co., who are the pub-
lishers of the World's Work, and so my letter very appropriate-
ly goes to him. Whether he will publish it, I do not know.
There does not seem to be a department for correspondence
in the World's Work. If he declines to publish it, we will
send it to the New York Times.

I hope all this meets your approval. With best
wishes,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. R. Kean,
Colonel, M.C., U.S. Army. Incl.
You will I am sure dear friend excuse
a short & dictated letter and I am
quite busy this morning, but do not want
to put off sending you this correspondence
I suppose you will have gone off to your
Blue Mountain before I get to Work- but
I will see you in the fall your J. R. K.
